borough: London Borough of Barking and Dagenham
decision_conditions: <p><span style="font-size:11pt;">The proposal, by reason of design and siting, would be an undesirable&nbsp;addition which does not have suitable access and is inappropriately located on a junction. As such, it fails to consider&nbsp;highway safety and the immediate surroundings, having a harmful impact on these. The proposal thus fails to comply with the following policies which seek to ensure that development proposals are designed to be&nbsp;appropriate within their context and promote safety, including highway safety:&nbsp;</span></p><ul><li><span style="font-size:11pt;">Paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework&nbsp;National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (DLUHC, 2021)</span></li><li><span style="font-size:11pt;">Policies&nbsp;D4 and GG1 of the London Plan (March 2021)</span></li><li><span style="font-size:11pt;">Policies CP2 and CP3 of the&nbsp;Local Development Framework (LDF) Core Strategy (July 2010)</span></li><li><span style="font-size:11pt;">Policies BR10, BP8 and BP11 of the&nbsp;Local Development Framework (LDF) Borough Wide Development Plan Document (DPD) (March 2011)</span></li><li><span style="font-size:11pt;">Sections 4.1 and 5.7&nbsp;of the Residential Extensions and Alterations Supplementary Planning Document (February 2012)</span></li><li><span style="font-size:11pt;">Policies SP2 and DMD6 of&nbsp;The London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021)</span></li></ul>

<p>The proposal, by reason of siting, mass, scale and design, would be an undesirable addition&nbsp;to this reduced size plot, which would reduce the outdoor amenity space to an unacceptable level. As such, it fails to protect residential amenity, having a harmful impact on the amenity of current and future occupiers on the site. The proposal thus fails to accord with the following policies which seek to ensure development proposals protect residential amenity:</p><p>Paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework&nbsp;National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (DLUHC, 2021)</p><p>Policy D6 of the London Plan (March 2021)</p><p>Policies&nbsp;BP8 and BP11 of the&nbsp;Local Development Framework (LDF) Borough Wide Development Plan Document (DPD) (March 2011)</p><p>Sections 4.2&nbsp;and 5.4 of the Residential Extensions and Alterations Supplementary Planning Document (February 2012)</p><p>Policies DMD1 and DMD6 of&nbsp;The London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021)</p>

<p>The proposal, by reason of scale, mass, design and siting, would be an undesirable addition which constitutes&nbsp;overdevelopment of the reduced size plot. As such, it fails to&nbsp;respect or reflect the character of the original dwelling, the terrace row of which it forms a part, and the surrounding area, causing harm to each of these.&nbsp;The proposal thus fails to accord with the following policies which seek to ensure development proposals are well designed and&nbsp;respect and reflect the existing character:</p><p>Paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework&nbsp;National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (DLUHC, 2021)</p><p>Policy&nbsp;D4&nbsp;of the London Plan (March 2021)</p><p>Policies CP2 and CP3 of the&nbsp;Local Development Framework (LDF) Core Strategy (July 2010)</p><p>Policies&nbsp;BP8 and BP11 of the&nbsp;Local Development Framework (LDF) Borough Wide Development Plan Document (DPD) (March 2011)</p><p>Sections 4.1 and 5.4 of the Residential Extensions and Alterations Supplementary Planning Document (February 2012)</p><p>Policies SP2 and DMD6 of&nbsp;The London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021)</p>
description: Construction of a single storey side extension
